Topics
pageTitle: Formica - by moke @ LumberJocks.com ~ woodworking community
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {4334=I have used Wilsonart and I like to work with it. I installed it in my own home in 1976 or 1977 and it was still serviceable when we sold the home in 2000. I think it is competitive with Formica. I have laid Formica brand plastic laminate that wanted to separate into layers and also had a 5’ x 12’ sheet that started breaking at an inside corner like it had internal stress. It wouldn’t stop cracking. The pieces were set back and used on a later job but it is funny stuff. I have no problem with Wilsonart but like you I have never heard of vertical laminate in my area., 17928=#8 posted 02-09-2012 03:45 PM, 16118=#7 posted 02-09-2012 12:41 AM, 4012=#1 posted 02-08-2012 06:30 PM, 7249=2141 posts in 1390 days, 9721=1124 posts in 1661 days, 11760=There are several brands of plastic laminate available, Formica, Nevamar, Wilsonart, and others that I can’t remember at the moment. Vertical grade laminate is for vertical surfaces only and will not stand up to the abuse of a countertop. Most of these brands are comparable in quality and should serve the purpose well. There is also a product called color-core that has the same color all the way through it. It works great for places you don’t want the dark line showing from the under layers of Formica and the others. Color-core is more brittle and more money but has it’s purpose. Be careful not to mix brands as each has their own “finish” and like colors of different brands may not match., 9873=#4 posted 02-08-2012 09:54 PM, 37456=©2015 Verticalscope Inc. All Rights Reserved. | Terms of Service | Privacy Policy, 5889=#2 posted 02-08-2012 06:35 PM, 13563=#6 posted 02-09-2012 12:16 AM, 16440=We used the color core laminate for heavily used surfaces in a doctor’s office in 1986. These were for work surfaces, secretaries’ stations and patient areas that we did not want to wear through and show brown patches. In the nurses’ work room with constant shifting of metal trays no wear through. It is more brittle but easy to use. Formica brand has a similar product. After 24 years still looks good., 1962=02-08-2012 06:24 PM, 11438=#5 posted 02-08-2012 10:28 PM, 7401=#3 posted 02-08-2012 06:39 PM}
textBeforeTable: Show all forums View all topics Start new topic signed in to reply. You must be Have your say... Awesome information!! Thank you all, I now have a good base line of what to look for.. Mike #8 posted 02-09-2012 03:45 PM 659 posts in 1746 days home | projects | blog moke -- Sam, upstate We used the color core laminate for heavily used surfaces in a doctor’s office in 1986. These were for work surfaces, secretaries’ stations and patient areas that we did not want to wear through and show brown patches. In the nurses’ work room with constant shifting of metal trays no wear through. It is more brittle but easy to use. Formica brand has a similar product. After 24 years still looks good.
